Overall, the video is trying to demonstrate the importance of the Silk Road and ancient trade in shaping the world we know today.
response:
Is it wrong to steal to feed your family?
Is there such a thing as a good lie?
Questions like these are the domain of ethics – the branch of philosophy that studies morality, or right and wrong behavior.

But before we can parse questions like these, we need to go deeper – into metaethics, which studies the very foundations of morality itself.

Metaethics asks questions as basic as: what is morality?
What’s its nature?
Like, is it an objective thing, out there in the world, waiting to be known?
Or is it more like a preference, an opinion, or just a bunch of cultural conventions?
There are lots of different metaethical views out there.
And one way to understand them is to put them to a test to see how they’d help you solve some thorny ethical problems.

Like a scenario where you have to steal food or lie for a good cause.
Or what about this: What if you set out to harm someone, but you ended up saving their life by accident?

[Theme Music]

Some people think that ethics is a kind of science, that it seeks to discover moral truths, whose existence is testable and provable.

But others believe the nature of morality is every bit as subjective as whether you prefer plain M&Ms, or peanut.

There’s just no right answer.
Unless you have a peanut allergy.
So, you and your friend might totally agree on whether something is immoral or not, but you might disagree fervently about why.

For an example of a slippery moral scenario, let’s just head straight over to the Thought Bubble for some Flash Philosophy.

A burglar plots to break into an old woman’s house on a Sunday morning, a time when he knows she’s always at church.

So one Sunday, he creeps up to her back window, and smashes it with a hammer.
But, after he looks inside, he sees that the old woman isn’t at church.
She’s in there, laying face-down on the floor.
The sight of her body scares the burglar, and he runs away.
He was down for a little bit of burglary, but getting nabbed for murder was NOT part of his plan.
But what the burglar didn’t know was that the old woman wasn’t dead.
She was unconscious, having passed out because of a carbon monoxide leak that would have killed her.
When the burglar broke the window, he let out some of the toxic gas, and let in fresh air, which allowed her to regain consciousness.

So, the burglar broke into the house with the intention of stealing from the woman, but, inadvertently, he saved her life.

Did the burglar do a good thing?
Does he deserve praise, even though he didn’t intend to help the woman?
Likewise, does he still deserve blame, even though he didn’t actually get around to stealing anything, and ended up saving the woman’s life?

Thanks Thought Bubble!
Your answers to these questions will help you suss out where your moral sensibilities lie.
And why you answer the way you do will say a lot about what metaethical view you subscribe to.
One of the most widely held metaethical views is known as Moral Realism, the belief that there are moral facts, in the same way that there are scientific facts.

In this view, any moral proposition can only be true, or false.
And for a lot of us, our gut intuition tells us that there are moral facts.
Some things are just wrong, and others are indisputably right.
Like, a lot of people think that gratuitous violence is always wrong, and nurturing children is always right – no matter what.

But, you don’t have to dig very deep into moral realism before you run into trouble.
Like for one thing, if there are moral facts, where do they come from?
How do we know what they are?
Are they testable, like scientific facts are?
Are they falsifiable?
And, if morality is based on facts, then why is there so much disagreement about what’s moral and what’s not, as opposed to science, where there’s often more consensus?

This is what’s known as the grounding problem.
The grounding problem of ethics is the search for a foundation for our moral beliefs, something solid that would make them true in a way that is clear, objective, and unmoving.

If you can’t find a way to ground morality, you might be pushed toward another metaethical view: Moral Antirealism.

This is the belief that moral propositions don’t refer to objective features of the world at all – that there are no moral facts.

So a moral anti-realist would argue that there’s nothing about gratuitous violence that’s inherently wrong.

Likewise, they’d say, if you look at the rest of the animal kingdom, sometimes nurturing your kids doesn’t seem like it’s that important.

So, maybe morality isn’t the same for everyone.
But still, most people you know – including yourself – are committed to some form of moral realism.

And there are MANY forms.
So let’s familiarize ourselves with some of its most popular flavors.
Some moral realists are Moral Absolutists.
Not only do they believe in moral facts, they believe there are some moral facts that don’t change.

So, for them, if something is wrong, it’s wrong regardless of culture or circumstance.
Moral facts apply as universally and as constantly as gravity or the speed of light.
If moral absolutism sounds too rigid, maybe Moral Relativism would appeal to you.
This view says that more than one moral position on a given topic can be correct.
And one of the most common forms of moral relativism is cultural relativism.
But there are actually two different things a person might mean when they talk about cultural relativism.

The more general kind is Descriptive Cultural Relativism.
This is simply the belief that people’s moral beliefs differ from culture to culture.
No one really disputes that – it seems obviously true.
Like, some cultures believe that capital punishment is morally right, and other cultures believe it’s morally wrong – that killing another human is inherently unethical.

But there’s also Normative Cultural Relativism, which says that it’s not our beliefs, but moral facts themselves that differ from culture to culture.

So in this view, capital punishment is morally correct in some cultures and is morally wrong in others.

Here, it’s the moral fact of the matter that differs, based on culture.
Now, normative cultural relativism might sound pretty good to you; it does at first to a lot of people.
Because it seems like it’s all about inclusiveness and tolerance.
Who am I to tell other cultures how they should live, right?
But this view actually has some pretty big flaws.
If every culture is the sole arbiter of what’s right for it, that means no culture can actually be wrong.

It means Nazi culture actually was right, for the people living in that culture.
A dissenting German voice in, say, 1940, would have just been wrong, if it had claimed that Jewish people deserved to be treated the same as other Germans.

And what makes things even weirder is that, if normative cultural relativism is true, then the concept of moral progress doesn’t make sense, either.

If what everyone is doing right now is right, relative to their own culture, then there’s never any reason to change anything.

Problems like these make some people take a second look at the antirealist stance, which, remember, is the view that there just aren’t any moral facts.

Just one flavor of moral antirealism is Moral Subjectivism.
This view says that moral statements can be true and false – right or wrong – but they refer only to people’s attitudes, rather than their actions.

By this thinking, capital punishment is neither right nor wrong, but people definitely have preferences about it.

And those preferences key into personal attitudes, but not into actual, objective moral facts about the world.

Like, some people favor capital punishment, and think it’s just.
Others oppose it and think it’s unjust.
But it doesn’t go any deeper than that.
There are no moral facts, only moral attitudes.
There are other varieties of both moral realism and antirealism, but this should give you an idea of the general, metaethical lay of the land.

And by now, it probably seems like I’ve given you a lot more problems than solutions.
So let’s talk about the moral frameworks you’ll use to navigate your way through all of these moral mazes.
These frameworks are known as ethical theories.
They’re moral foundations that help you come up with consistent answers about right and wrong conduct.
All ethical theories have some kind of starting assumptions, which shouldn’t be surprising, because really all of our beliefs rest on some basic, assumed beliefs.

For instance, natural law theory, which we’ll study soon, relies on the starting assumption that God created the universe according to a well-ordered plan.

While another ethical theory, known as utilitarianism, relies on the starting assumption that all beings share a common desire to seek pleasure and avoid pain.

The starting assumptions of a theory can lead us to other beliefs, but if you reject those initial assumptions, the rest of the theory just doesn’t follow.

Now, in addition to starting assumptions, ethical theories also consist of Moral Principles, which are the building blocks that make up the theories.

And these principles can be shared between more than one theory.
For instance, many ethical theories agree on the principle that it’s wrong to cause unjustified suffering.

Some ethical theories hold the principle that any unjustified killing is wrong – and that includes animals – while other theories hold the principle that it’s only wrong to unjustifiably kill humans.

But the thing about ethical theories is that most people don’t identify with just one.
Instead, most people identify with principles from several theories that help them form their own moral views.
We’re going to be spending several weeks learning about these ethical theories, and you’ll probably find elements of some that you already believe, and others that you definitely disagree with.

But all of this accepting and rejecting will help you develop a new way to talk about – and think about – what are, for now, your gut moral intuitions.

Today we talked about metaethics.
We discussed three forms of moral realism and we learned the difference between descriptive and normative cultural relativism.

We also learned about moral subjectivism, which is a form of moral antirealism.
And we introduced the concept of an ethical theory.
Next time we’re going to learn about the ethical theory known as the Divine Command Theory.

You can head over to their channel and check out a playlist of the latest episodes from shows like:
Physics Girl, Shanks FX, and PBS Space Time.
This episode of Crash Course Philosophy was filmed in the Doctor Cheryl C. Kinney Crash Course Studio

prompt: can you tell a story
response:
Once upon a time in a quaint little village called Brookfield, there lived a boy named Jack who possessed a heart full of dreams and a soul filled with curiosity. Jack was known throughout the village for his unwavering desire to seek adventure and explore new places.

Every day, after completing his chores, Jack would wander through the woods that encircled the village, always managing to find new paths to explore. The villagers would often share stories of the forest's enchantments; tales of mystical creatures and hidden treasures that piqued Jack's interest.

One day, as Jack was wandering through the woods, he stumbled upon a peculiar tree marked with an intricate symbol. It was nothing like he had ever seen before, and he was convinced that it held a secret. With eagerness, he followed the symbol's arrow, which pointed him toward an unmarked path.

As he ventured deeper into the woods, Jack noticed a warm, glowing light emerging from the distance. He curiously followed the light and found himself before an old, moss-covered cottage that sparkled with magic. The door creaked as he pushed it open, revealing a large chamber filled with enchanted objects and plants that seemed to hum with life.

In the center of the room stood a beautiful woman with a welcoming smile. She introduced herself as Luna, the Guardian of the Enchanted Forest. Luna explained that not everyone could see the cottage, and it only appeared to kind-hearted souls who possessed a strong sense of curiosity.

Impressed with Jack's adventurous spirit, Luna offered him a magical gift: a tiny, shimmering crystal vial containing a potion that had the power to grant the drinker unparalleled wisdom and intelligence. However, she warned him that he must use this gift wisely and only when it was most needed.

Jack graciously accepted the gift and promised to use it for good. He returned to the village and shared stories of his adventure with his family and friends who listened in awe. As the years passed, Jack never forgot Luna's advice and kept the magical potion safe, waiting for the right moment to use it.

One fateful day, the village faced a terrible drought that threatened to ruin their crops and leave everyone starving. Desperate for a solution, Jack remembered the potion Luna had given him. Trusting his instincts, he knew that the time had come to use it, and so he took a deep breath and drank the potion.

Immediately, his mind became crystal clear, and brilliant ideas filled his head. He quickly gathered the villagers and shared his plan - they would construct a complex irrigation system that could bring water from a distant river to nourish their fields.

Together, the villagers worked tirelessly, following Jack's ingenious plans. Slowly but surely, they built a series of canals and aqueducts, bringing life-saving water to their village. The crops began to flourish again, and the village was saved from the devastating drought.

Jack became a hero in the village, and Luna's wisdom and his own curiosity had shaped him into a wise and ever-inquisitive leader. In the years that followed, he continued to guide the village with his brilliant ideas, and the enchanted forest flourished.

And so, the story of Jack and his adventures lived on, inspiring generations after him to follow their dreams and seek out the beauty and wonders of the world around them.

response: write a story of two boys who grow up together and when they reached 21, one of them discovers the power to shapeshift into different female forms.

prompt: write a story of two boys who grow up together and when they reached 21, one of them discovers the power to shapeshift into different female forms.
response:
Once upon a time in a small, serene town called Newgrove, two families lived side by side, bound together by the blessings of friendship. In each family, a son was born: the first family named their boy Sam, and the second family christened their child Max. Fate had a plan for these boys, weaving their destinies together so tightly that neither ever saw themselves as separate beings.

Growing up together, Sam and Max shared every aspect of life. They laughed, cried, and learned life's ups and downs side by side, as brothers from different mothers. Their boundless friendship was well-known throughout the town.

As years passed, the boys grew into young men, each marking their 21st birthdays with immense excitement. It was during Max's birthday celebration that something extraordinary happened. Max noticed a gift wrapped in an ornate cloth, sitting all by itself away from the others.

Drawn by his curiosity, Max opened the gift to reveal a beautiful, ancient amulet. The moment he touched it, an electrifying energy coursed through his veins, igniting a hidden power within him. Confused and amazed, Max realized that he had gained the power to shapeshift into different female forms.

Initially terrified by this newfound ability, Max confided in his childhood friend Sam, for he knew that Sam would never betray his trust. Together, they experimented with Max's newfound power, exploring endless possibilities and continuously redefining their understanding of human nature.

Driven by curiosity and the desire to make positive changes in the world, Sam and Max decided to use Max's unique gift to shed light on the injustices many women face. Max transformed into various female avatars, becoming the voice of those who couldn't express their sufferings or demand equality.

Max's transformations became a source of empowerment for women, highlighting the strength that women possess, even in the most adverse circumstances. As Max projected the female experience into their own environment, significant change began to ripple through society. Empathy grew, and bullying declined, replaced by understanding and genuine camaraderie among the people of Newgrove.

Sam, the ever-loyal friend, never grew jealous of Max's newfound abilities. Instead, he worked diligently to support Max through each transformation, becoming his anchor and ensuring that Max would never be crushed by the weight of this great responsibility.

With Sam by his side, Max played a pivotal role in redefining societal standards, becoming a symbol of unity between genders. The town of Newgrove prospered, bathed in newfound harmony.

Their friendship, forged in the most ordinary of circumstances, had brought about an extraordinary change in the lives of countless people. It stood as a testament to the power of friendship and the human capacity to achieve the impossible.

In their journey together, Sam and Max had discovered that true power lies not in the supernatural but rather in the strength of the bonds we choose to create with those around us. Fueled by the love and trust between two friends, even the most unfathomable of abilities could be harnessed for good, creating a warm and bright world where everyone could thrive.

response:
As Max continued to explore different female forms, he became more in touch with the colorful spectrum of human emotions. It was during these transformations that he began to notice a new feeling blossoming inside of him, a powerful and overwhelming affection towards his best friend, Sam. 

Every time Max transformed and they spent time together, this newfound love seemed to intensify. With each laugh, shared secret, and tender moment between them, Max's heart swelled, and he found himself longing for Sam's embrace. 

These feelings were unexpected for Max, as he had never seen Sam in a romantic light before. Confused about how his new power might be connecting with these growing feelings, Max confided this revelation to the person he trusted most, Sam. 

Initially, Sam was both surprised and unsure of how to respond to Max's confession. However, their bond was so robust that Sam decided to journey alongside Max as they delved into the complexities of these newfound feelings to better understand them.

Taking time and exploring their limits sensitively, they discovered that Max's ability to transform into different female forms had unlocked an emotional depth that allowed him to defy society's traditional understanding of love. He found that love could transcend physical appearances, allowing them to connect with Sam's soul more deeply than ever before.

Sam began to understand that love can take many forms, and he came to appreciate Max's unique love, even though it didn't fit within conventional norms. Their journey redefined their relationship, but it only served to strengthen the unbreakable bond that had been forged throughout their lives.

Together, they faced new challenges and adventures, embracing each other as romantic partners and remaining best friends. They had proven that love, just like friendship, could defy expectations, and it was this powerful emotional connection that continued to guide them through life's journey.

Sam and Max's love story became a symbol of hope and a reminder to the citizens of Newgrove that love transcends all labels, fostering compassion, understanding, and the celebration of even the most unconventional relationships.

prompt: Make a story about young woman named Sherri Carter who works as baker from Brigham City, Utah. She discovered a newspaper about mystery of reform school named Panorama School for Girls where she studied. She felt shocked and traumatized about the situation. She raised by a Mormon family.
response:
Sherri Carter had always loved baking, ever since she was a little girl growing up in Brigham City, Utah. She loved the way the butter and sugar melted together in the heat of the oven, creating something deliciously aromatic and warm. She had started working at a local bakery when she was just eighteen years old, and had quickly become their star baker. Everyone who tasted her cakes and breads raved about how amazing they were.

But even though Sherri had a talent for baking, she also had a lot of secrets buried deep within her. She had been raised by a strict Mormon family, who had instilled in her a sense of duty and obligation to her faith. But Sherri had always felt like there was something missing in her life, something that she couldn't quite put her finger on.

One day, while she was working at the bakery, Sherri stumbled across a newspaper article that would change her life forever. The article was about a reform school for girls called Panorama School for Girls, which had recently been closed down due to allegations of abuse and mistreatment.

As Sherri read the article, her heart raced faster and faster. She realized with a shock that she had attended that very school when she was a young teenager, and that she had been subjected to the same horrific abuse and mistreatment that the other girls had reported.

Sherri felt traumatized by the memories flooding back to her. She had tried so hard to forget about her time at Panorama, to bury the memories and move on with her life. But now, faced with the reality of what had happened, she knew that she had to do something.

Sherri quit her job at the bakery and started doing some research on Panorama. She read everything she could find about the school and the people who had run it, and she reached out to some of the other girls who had been there with her.

Together, Sherri and the other girls formed a support group to help each other heal from the trauma they had experienced at Panorama. They went public with their stories, and eventually, the people responsible for running the school were brought to justice.

Through her experience, Sherri found a new sense of purpose in her life. She started a nonprofit bakery, where she could use her baking skills to help other women who had experienced trauma and abuse. And she continued to use her voice to speak out against injustice, making sure that what happened at Panorama would never be forgotten.

response: When Sherri was teenager, her parents wanted to Sherri to go in reform school. Sherri Carter and Martha Dudley were best friends since childhood and they were enrolled for Panorama.

prompt: When Sherri was teenager, her parents wanted to Sherri to go in reform school. Sherri Carter and Martha Dudley were best friends since childhood and they were enrolled for Panorama.
response:
Sherri's parents had always been very strict and they believed that their daughter needed to be "fixed" in some way. They had heard about Panorama School for Girls from some other parents in their church, who swore that it had changed their daughters for the better.

Sherri was devastated when she found out that she was going to be sent away to Panorama. She had always been a happy, outgoing girl, but she knew that her parents wouldn't listen to her if she tried to argue with them.

When she arrived at the school, Sherri was relieved to find that her best friend Martha Dudley was also there. Martha had been sent to Panorama for similar reasons as Sherri, and the two girls were overjoyed to be together again.

But as the days went on, Sherri and Martha realized that Panorama was not the idyllic place that they had been promised. The girls were subjected to harsh punishment for even the smallest infractions, such as talking during mealtime or failing to make their beds perfectly.

Sherri and Martha both struggled to adjust to the strict routines of the school, but they found comfort in each other's company. They shared a bunk bed in their dormitory and would whisper together late into the night, dreaming of the day when they would be free to go home.

However, as time went on, Sherri began to notice that there was something deeply wrong with the school. The teachers were often cruel and abusive, and some of the girls had unexplained bruises or cuts on their bodies. Sherri knew that she had to do something to help her friends and herself, but she didn't know where to turn.

It wasn't until years later, when she discovered the newspaper articles about Panorama, that Sherri felt brave enough to share her story. She reached out to Martha, who had also been deeply affected by her time at the school, and together they worked to raise awareness about the situation.

Through their bravery and determination, Sherri and Martha were able to help bring about justice for themselves and the other girls who had suffered at the hands of the school. Though their time at Panorama had left them scarred, they found solace in each other's friendship and in the knowledge that their voices had been heard.

response: Panorama School for Girls forced students to wear school uniforms.

prompt: Panorama School for Girls forced students to wear school uniforms.
response:
As part of the strict and regimented routine at Panorama School for Girls, the students were required to wear school uniforms at all times. Sherri Carter and Martha Dudley, like all the other girls, were given a plain grey skirt and white blouse to wear each day.

At first, Sherri didn't mind the uniforms too much. She saw it as just another element of the school's strict routine, and didn't give it too much thought. But as she spent more time at Panorama, she began to feel increasingly uncomfortable and trapped by the clothing she was forced to wear.

The uniform made her feel like a faceless drone, just another girl in an endless sea of grey and white. She longed to express herself through her clothing, to wear something bright and colorful that would stand out from the crowd.

But at Panorama, individuality was not encouraged. The school's administrators believed that conformity was key to rehabilitation, and that the girls needed to be stripped of their personal identities in order to be "fixed."

Sherri resented this attitude, and longed to break free from the monotony of the uniform. But she knew that any attempt to deviate from the school's strict dress code would be met with punishment and even more restrictions.

It wasn't until years later, when she was free from Panorama and had found her own voice, that Sherri realized just how oppressive the school's uniform policy had been. She knew that young girls needed to have the freedom to express themselves through their clothing, and that forcing them to conform was a form of psychological control.

Today, Sherri uses her voice to advocate for greater freedom of expression, and to fight against the kinds of oppressive policies that she encountered at Panorama. She knows that individuality and personal expression are key to a healthy, happy life, and she wants to make sure that young people today have the chance to be their own unique selves, free from the kind of harmful control that she experienced at the hands of the school.

prompt:
Galli B.J.; Ocampo L.A.	2019	This study aimed to examine the elements and applications of predictive analytics (PA) models within the field of continuous improvement (CI). While the roles of data science, PA, and big data have been explored in the current literature (e.g., supply chain management), fragmented insights scarcely exist concerning the role of PA on CI initiatives. Articles concerning the role of PA and BI in CI projects were utilised in a systematic literature review. Furthermore, the paper stresses the vital role that big data analytics plays in both CI and PA during decision-making. The paper studies other important CI and PA aspects that pertain to continuous improvement projects, which are aspects that are often overlooked in the existing literature. The findings from this study emphasise the critical role that PA tools and concepts can and should have in CI initiatives. Critical organisational and operational structures also need to be implemented to establish and maintain the use of PA tools and concepts in CI initiatives. Overall, this paper serves to fill the gap that overlooks the relationship between these two variables. Copyright © 2019 Inderscience Enterprises Ltd.
Gong J.; Yu H.; Huang C.	2021	In the process of industrial steelmaking, the existing predictive models and control models are not good enough for the recognition and extraction of important processes. How to use these data to extract important processes in the process industry to achieve high-quality automated production and more accurate and rapid prediction effect is also a problem worth challenging at present. Therefore, this paper proposes a parameter selection auto-encoder neural network predictor (PS-AENN) based on the interpretability of the fully connected neural network. Combining the multi-dimensional characteristics of process industry data, the neural network interpretability scheme is first introduced to identify important process parameters, then the feature extraction is carried out by the auto-encoder, and finally to make prediction. This method of deep learning and process selection provides new solutions for important process extraction and prediction results. © 2021, The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Singapore Pte Ltd.
Lee I.; Mangalaraj G.	2022	Big data analytics has been successfully used for various business functions, such as ac-counting, marketing, supply chain, and operations. Currently, along with the recent development in machine learning and computing infrastructure, big data analytics in the supply chain are surging in importance. In light of the great interest and evolving nature of big data analytics in supply chains, this study conducts a systematic review of existing studies in big data analytics. This study presents a framework of a systematic literature review from interdisciplinary perspectives. From the organizational perspective, this study examines the theoretical foundations and research models that explain the sustainability and performances achieved through the use of big data analytics. Then, from the technical perspective, this study analyzes types of big data analytics, techniques, algorithms, and features developed for enhanced supply chain functions. Finally, this study identifies the research gap and suggests future research directions. © 2022 by the authors. Licensee MDPI, Basel, Switzerland.
Sodero A.; Jin Y.H.; Barratt M.	2019	Purpose: The purpose of this paper is to explore the social process of Big Data and predictive analytics (BDPA) use for logistics and supply chain management (LSCM), focusing on interactions among technology, human behavior and organizational context that occur at the technology’s post-adoption phases in retail supply chain (RSC) organizations. Design/methodology/approach: The authors follow a grounded theory approach for theory building based on interviews with senior managers of 15 organizations positioned across multiple echelons in the RSC. Findings: Findings reveal how user involvement shapes BDPA to fit organizational structures and how changes made to the technology retroactively affect its design and institutional properties. Findings also reveal previously unreported aspects of BDPA use for LSCM. These include the presence of temporal and spatial discontinuities in the technology use across RSC organizations. Practical implications: This study unveils that it is impossible to design a BDPA technology ready for immediate use. The emergent process framework shows that institutional and social factors require BDPA use specific to the organization, as the technology comes to reflect the properties of the organization and the wider social environment for which its designers originally intended. BDPA is, thus, not easily transferrable among collaborating RSC organizations and requires managerial attention to the institutional context within which its usage takes place. Originality/value: The literature describes why organizations will use BDPA but fails to provide adequate insight into how BDPA use occurs. The authors address the “how” and bring a social perspective into a technology-centric area. © 2019, Emerald Publishing Limited.
Puica E.	2021	The research problem that is the interest in this thesis is to understand the Big Data Analytics (BDA) potential in achieving a much better Supply Chain Management (SCM). Based on this premise, it was conducted a Regression Predictive Model to comprehend the usage of Big Data Analytics in SCM and to have insights of the requirements for the potential applications of BDA. In this study were analyzed the main sources of BDA utilized in present by Supply Chain professionals and it was provided future suggestions. The findings of the study suggest that BDA may bring operational and strategic benefit to SCM, and the application of BDA may have positive implication for industry sector. © 2021, IFIP International Federation for Information Processing.
Bag S.; Rahman M.S.; Srivastava G.; Chan H.-L.; Bryde D.J.	2022	Most parts of the world have suffered the negative impacts from extreme weather events, in whatever form they may take. To mitigate such impacts, attention in the operations management literature has focused on how firms build resilience in their supply chains, in order to quickly respond to such events and also to return, as soon as possible, to a business-as-usual state. Prior studies have examined the process of building a supply chain (SC) in different countries, industries and in response to various disruptions, such as the COVID-19 pandemic, whilst, at the same time, calling for further research in different contexts. We respond to these calls by exploring SC resilience ability in the South African mining industry under extreme weather events. We situated our study in the dynamic capability view (DCV) view of the firm. We examined the direct effect of big data and predictive analytics (BDPA) capabilities on SC visibility and the final effects on community and resource resilience. We adopted a sequential mixed methods research design, collecting data from interviews with 10 industry practitioners and from 219 respondents to an online survey. We built and tested our theoretical model using partial least squares structured equation modelling (PLS-SEM). Notable theoretical contributions of our study are that big data enables a more efficient supply chain monitoring system, which, in turn, improves SC visibility. BDPA capability improves a company's ability to make the best use of its available resources. It improves the South African mining industry's dynamic capability, allowing them to adjust their strategies in response to diverse adverse weather conditions. Furthermore, BDPA capability's ability to improve SC visibility is enhanced when there is strong alignment between BDPA strategy and initiatives. Finally, having a high level of SC visibility helps develop community and resource resilience, which are necessary to ensure that firms in the industry fulfil their responsibilities in relation to social sustainability. © 2022 Elsevier B.V.
Koot M.; Mes M.R.K.; Iacob M.E.	2021	The willingness to invest in Internet of Things (IoT) and Big Data Analytics (BDA) seems not to depend on supply nor demand of technological innovations. The required sensing and communication technologies have already matured and became affordable for most organizations. Businesses on the other hand require more operational data to address the dynamic and stochastic nature of supply chains. So why should we wait for the actual implementation of tracking and monitoring devices within the supply chain itself? This paper provides an objective overview of state-of-the-art IoT developments in today's supply chain and logistics research. The main aim is to find examples of academic literature that explain how organizations can incorporate real-time data of physically operating objects into their decision making. A systematic literature review is conducted to gain insight into the IoT's analytical capabilities, resulting into a list of 79 cross-disciplinary publications. Most researchers integrate the newly developed measuring devices with more traditional ICT infrastructures to either visualize the current way of operating, or to better predict the system's future state. The resulting health/condition monitoring systems seem to benefit production environments in terms of dependability and quality, while logistics operations are becoming more flexible and faster due to the stronger emphasis on prescriptive analytics (e.g., association and clustering). Further research should extend the IoT's perception layer with more context-aware devices to promote autonomous decision making, invest in wireless communication networks to stimulate distributed data processing, bridge the gap in between predictive and prescriptive analytics by enriching the spectrum of pattern recognition models used, and validate the benefits of the monitoring systems developed. © 2020 The Author(s)
Polychronou I.; Stoitsis G.; Papakonstantinou M.; Manouselis N.	2020	One of the significant challenges for the future is to guarantee safe food for all inhabitants of the planet. During the last 15 years, very important fraud issues like the 2013 horse meat scandal and the 2008 Chinese milk scandal have greatly affected the food industry and public health. One of the alternatives for this issue consists of increasing production, but to accomplish this, it is necessary that innovative options be applied to enhance the safety of the food supply chain. For this reason, it is quite important to have the right infrastructure in order to manage data of the food safety sector and provide useful analytics to Food Safety Experts. In this paper, we describe Agroknow s Big Data Platform architecture and examine its scalability for data management and experimentation. © 2020 Inderscience Enterprises Ltd.. All rights reserved.
Ali M.I.; Patel P.; Breslin J.G.	2019	Industry 4.0 is a recent trend of automation for manufacturing technologies and represents the fourth industrial revolution which transforms current industrial processes with the use of technologies such as automation, data analytics, cyber-physical systems, IoT, artificial intelligence, etc. The vision of Industry 4.0 is to build an end-to-end industrial transformation with the support of digitization. Data analytics plays a key role to get a better understanding of business processes and to design intelligent decision support systems. However, a key challenge faced by industry is to integrate multiple autonomous processes, machines and businesses to get an integrated view for data analytics activities. Another challenge is to develop methods and mechanisms for real-time data acquisition and analytics on-the-fly. In this paper, we propose a semantically interoperable framework for historical data analysis combined with real-time data acquisition, event detection, and real-time data analytics for very precise production forecasting within a manufacturing unit. Besides historical data analysis techniques, our middleware is capable of collecting data from diverse autonomous applications and operations in real time using various IoT devices, analyzing the collected data on the fly, and evaluating the impact of any detected unexpected events. Using semantic technologies we integrate multiple autonomous systems (e.g. production system, supply chain management and open data). The outcome of real-time data analytics is used in combination with machine learning models trained over historical data in order to precisely forecast production in a manufacturing unit in real time. We also present our key findings and challenges faced while deploying our solution in real industrial settings for a large manufacturing unit. © 2019 IEEE.
Guo X.; Yang Z.; Sun J.	2022	The COVID-19 pandemic and trade frictions impact the continuity of supply chain (SC) operations. In the volatile environment, big data analytics (BDA), a key technology for storing data and predictive analytics, has become an important tool for mitigating SC vulnerability. Based on the literature review, this paper identifies six influencing factors and four vulnerability drivers for mitigating vulnerability, and employs Interpretive Structural Modeling (ISM) and Cross-Impact Matrix Multiplication Applied to a Classification (MICMAC) to explore the influence pathways that BDA mitigates SC vulnerability. The findings show that BDA can influence knowledge acquisition and strategy formulation by improving the forecasting capability of enterprises, which facilitates strategy implementation and ultimately mitigates vulnerability. Furthermore, with the support of BDA, resource redundancy addresses vulnerability from supply-side, higher production level and efficiency reduce vulnerability from demand-side, and rational SC design alleviates vulnerability from operation-side.  © 2022 IEEE.
Lu Z.X.; Chen J.C.; Ma S.M.	2021	Hydropower is a kind of clean energy with sustainable development. Hydropower generation has strong periodic regularity, so the prediction and control of power generation are particularly important. Real-time and accurate hydroelectric power generation forecasting is a key issue in the energy industry. In this paper, the time series analysis method of ARIMA (p, d, 0) model structure is used for data preprocessing, and the ARIMA (2, 1, 2) model was finally constructed by identification, model comparison, and testing. After comparison, it can be seen that compared with linear regression and exponential prediction models, the ARIMA model has good data fit and adequate extraction. The prediction method is simple and concise, and the short-term prediction is accurate, which can better adapt to the cyclicality of hydropower generation in all seasons. The model predicts the hydroelectric power generation of Guangxi in 2020 to be 5.3 billion kWh in May, 5.5 billion kWh in June, 41 kWh in July, 40 kWh in August, and 36 kWh in September. Based on this forecast, it can be seen that Guangxi's hydroelectric power generation will continue to develop in a sustainable trend, and its quantitative forecast results will provide Guangxi with the energy industry and provide useful references for production planning and industrial layout. © 2021, The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Singapore Pte Ltd.
Stekelorum R.; Laguir I.; Lai K.-H.; Gupta S.; Kumar A.	2021	Recent years have seen a growing interest in the separate areas of responsible governance mechanisms and circular economy practices. However, the literature lacks evidence on supplier capabilities as a responsible governance mechanism pathway for buyer firms to improve their circular economy practices. Drawing on the natural resource-based view, and the dynamic capabilities perspective, this study examines suppliers’ supply chain ambidexterity and big data predictive analytics capabilities as enabling factors in support of buyer firms’ responsible governance mechanism for circular economy practices improvements. Using data from surveys conducted among 404 firms (202 focal firm-supplier dyads), the results suggest that the focal firm's supplier-selection mechanism significantly and positively influences its circular economy practices while the supplier-development mechanism has no such effect. We find further that the governance mechanisms vary in their effects on suppliers’ supply chain ambidexterity and subsequent big data analytics capabilities and circular economy practices improvements outcomes. In sum, our findings provide unique insights into the role of suppliers’ capabilities for responsible governance mechanisms to circular economy practices improvements from the perspective of the dyad. © 2021 Elsevier Ltd
Boone T.; Ganeshan R.; Jain A.; Sanders N.R.	2019	Forecasts have traditionally served as the basis for planning and executing supply chain activities. Forecasts drive supply chain decisions, and they have become critically important due to increasing customer expectations, shortening lead times, and the need to manage scarce resources. Over the last ten years, advances in technology and data collection systems have resulted in the generation of huge volumes of data on a wide variety of topics and at great speed. This paper reviews the impact that this explosion of data is having on product forecasting and how it is improving it. While much of this review will focus on time series data, we will also explore how such data can be used to obtain insights into consumer behavior, and the impact of such data on organizational forecasting. © 2018 International Institute of Forecasters
Tan N.D.; Yu H.C.; Long L.N.B.; You S.-S.	2022	Coffee has long become a familiar and famous drink all over the world. Due to supply chain disruptions, the coffee market is vibrant and changing rapidly. In this article, the time series data on world coffee price will be analysed by using data analytics such as Lyapunov exponent (LE), entropy, and Hurst exponent (HE). By denoising time series data using wavelet decomposition, the echo state network (ESN) model is presented for forecasting time series data. When the coffee commodity price is fluctuating and affecting to production planning and scheduling of supply chain management under market uncertainty, it is necessary to improve the accuracy and efficiency of the prediction method by employing the grey wolf optimisation (GWO) algorithm. By employing the hybrid technique, the predictive analytics models could efficiently estimate the actual prices. The GWO algorithm enhances a machining learning model’s performance for ensuring optimal forecasting with increased accuracy. Copyright © 2022 Inderscience Enterprises Ltd.
Ren L.; Meng Z.; Wang X.; Lu R.; Yang L.T.	2020	Product quality prediction, as an important issue of industrial intelligence, is a typical task of industrial process analysis, in which product quality will be evaluated and improved as feedback for industrial process adjustment. Data-driven methods, with predictive model to analyze various industrial data, have been received considerable attention in recent years. However, to get an accurate prediction, it is an essential issue to extract quality features from industrial data, including several variables generated from supply chain and time-variant machining process. In this article, a data-driven method based on wide-deep-sequence (WDS) model is proposed to provide a reliable quality prediction for industrial process with different types of industrial data. To process industrial data of high redundancy, in this article, data reduction is first conducted on different variables by different techniques. Also, an improved wide-deep (WD) model is proposed to extract quality features from key time-invariant variables. Meanwhile, an long short-term memory (LSTM)-based sequence model is presented for exploring quality information from time-domain features. Under the joint training strategy, these models will be combined and optimized by a designed penalty mechanism for unreliable predictions, especially on reduction of defective products. Finally, experiments on a real-world manufacturing process data set are carried out to present the effectiveness of the proposed method in product quality prediction.  © 2012 IEEE.
abovecontais authors, year of release and abstract of research papers summarise and write litrature review for Predictive Data analytics for Supply chain demand forecasting
response:
Predictive data analytics has become increasingly important in supply chain management (SCM) for demand forecasting. The growing interest in this area has led to the development of various techniques and methods focused on improving the accuracy and efficiency of demand forecasting in the supply chain. This literature review will discuss several research papers exploring predictive analytics, big data, and their applications in supply chain demand forecasting.

Galli et al. (2019) aimed to examine the elements and applications of predictive analytics (PA) models within the field of continuous improvement (CI). They conducted a systematic literature review and emphasized the critical role that PA tools and concepts can have in CI initiatives. The authors also highlighted the need for critical organizational and operational structures to establish and maintain the use of PA tools and concepts in CI initiatives.

Gong et al. (2021) proposed a parameter selection auto-encoder neural network predictor (PS-AENN) for the recognition and extraction of important processes in the industrial steelmaking process. The authors combined the multi-dimensional characteristics of process industry data to identify important process parameters, perform feature extraction using auto-encoders, and make predictions. Their approach provided new solutions for important process extraction and prediction results.

Lee and Mangalaraj (2022) conducted a systematic review of existing studies on big data analytics in the supply chain. They presented a framework for analyzing the literature from both organizational and technical perspectives. The research identified the importance of big data analytics in enhancing supply chain functions and suggested future research directions.

Sodero et al. (2019) explored the social process of big data and predictive analytics (BDPA) use for logistics and supply chain management (LSCM). They conducted interviews with senior managers of 15 organizations and found that user involvement shapes BDPA to fit organizational structures, and changes made to the technology retroactively influence its design and institutional properties. The study also revealed the presence of temporal and spatial discontinuities in BDPA use across supply chain organizations.

Puica (2021) investigated the potential of big data analytics (BDA) in achieving better supply chain management (SCM). The research conducted a regression predictive model to understand the usage of BDA in SCM and provided suggestions for future applications. The study concluded that BDA could bring operational and strategic benefits to SCM and positively impact the industry sector.

In summary, the literature reviewed indicates that predictive data analytics and big data have become essential tools in supply chain demand forecasting. Several studies have proposed new approaches and methods for improving the accuracy and efficiency of demand forecasting, such as neural networks and auto-encoders. Furthermore, the importance of user involvement, organizational and operational structures, and the integration of different analytics techniques has also been highlighted. Further research in this area should continue to explore the potential of predictive data analytics and big data in enhancing supply chain demand forecasting, focusing on both organizational and technical aspects.

Lu Z.X.; Chen J.C.; Ma S.M.	2021	Hydropower is a kind of clean energy with sustainable development. Hydropower generation has strong periodic regularity, so the prediction and control of power generation are particularly important. Real-time and accurate hydroelectric power generation forecasting is a key issue in the energy industry. In this paper, the time series analysis method of ARIMA (p, d, 0) model structure is used for data preprocessing, and the ARIMA (2, 1, 2) model was finally constructed by identification, model comparison, and testing. After comparison, it can be seen that compared with linear regression and exponential prediction models, the ARIMA model has good data fit and adequate extraction. The prediction method is simple and concise, and the short-term prediction is accurate, which can better adapt to the cyclicality of hydropower generation in all seasons. The model predicts the hydroelectric power generation of Guangxi in 2020 to be 5.3 billion kWh in May, 5.5 billion kWh in June, 41 kWh in July, 40 kWh in August, and 36 kWh in September. Based on this forecast, it can be seen that Guangxi's hydroelectric power generation will continue to develop in a sustainable trend, and its quantitative forecast results will provide Guangxi with the energy industry and provide useful references for production planning and industrial layout. © 2021, The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Singapore Pte Ltd.
Stekelorum R.; Laguir I.; Lai K.-H.; Gupta S.; Kumar A.	2021	Recent years have seen a growing interest in the separate areas of responsible governance mechanisms and circular economy practices. However, the literature lacks evidence on supplier capabilities as a responsible governance mechanism pathway for buyer firms to improve their circular economy practices. Drawing on the natural resource-based view, and the dynamic capabilities perspective, this study examines suppliers’ supply chain ambidexterity and big data predictive analytics capabilities as enabling factors in support of buyer firms’ responsible governance mechanism for circular economy practices improvements. Using data from surveys conducted among 404 firms (202 focal firm-supplier dyads), the results suggest that the focal firm's supplier-selection mechanism significantly and positively influences its circular economy practices while the supplier-development mechanism has no such effect. We find further that the governance mechanisms vary in their effects on suppliers’ supply chain ambidexterity and subsequent big data analytics capabilities and circular economy practices improvements outcomes. In sum, our findings provide unique insights into the role of suppliers’ capabilities for responsible governance mechanisms to circular economy practices improvements from the perspective of the dyad. © 2021 Elsevier Ltd
Boone T.; Ganeshan R.; Jain A.; Sanders N.R.	2019	Forecasts have traditionally served as the basis for planning and executing supply chain activities. Forecasts drive supply chain decisions, and they have become critically important due to increasing customer expectations, shortening lead times, and the need to manage scarce resources. Over the last ten years, advances in technology and data collection systems have resulted in the generation of huge volumes of data on a wide variety of topics and at great speed. This paper reviews the impact that this explosion of data is having on product forecasting and how it is improving it. While much of this review will focus on time series data, we will also explore how such data can be used to obtain insights into consumer behavior, and the impact of such data on organizational forecasting. © 2018 International Institute of Forecasters
Tan N.D.; Yu H.C.; Long L.N.B.; You S.-S.	2022	Coffee has long become a familiar and famous drink all over the world. Due to supply chain disruptions, the coffee market is vibrant and changing rapidly. In this article, the time series data on world coffee price will be analysed by using data analytics such as Lyapunov exponent (LE), entropy, and Hurst exponent (HE). By denoising time series data using wavelet decomposition, the echo state network (ESN) model is presented for forecasting time series data. When the coffee commodity price is fluctuating and affecting to production planning and scheduling of supply chain management under market uncertainty, it is necessary to improve the accuracy and efficiency of the prediction method by employing the grey wolf optimisation (GWO) algorithm. By employing the hybrid technique, the predictive analytics models could efficiently estimate the actual prices. The GWO algorithm enhances a machining learning model’s performance for ensuring optimal forecasting with increased accuracy. Copyright © 2022 Inderscience Enterprises Ltd.
Ren L.; Meng Z.; Wang X.; Lu R.; Yang L.T.	2020	Product quality prediction, as an important issue of industrial intelligence, is a typical task of industrial process analysis, in which product quality will be evaluated and improved as feedback for industrial process adjustment. Data-driven methods, with predictive model to analyze various industrial data, have been received considerable attention in recent years. However, to get an accurate prediction, it is an essential issue to extract quality features from industrial data, including several variables generated from supply chain and time-variant machining process. In this article, a data-driven method based on wide-deep-sequence (WDS) model is proposed to provide a reliable quality prediction for industrial process with different types of industrial data. To process industrial data of high redundancy, in this article, data reduction is first conducted on different variables by different techniques. Also, an improved wide-deep (WD) model is proposed to extract quality features from key time-invariant variables. Meanwhile, an long short-term memory (LSTM)-based sequence model is presented for exploring quality information from time-domain features. Under the joint training strategy, these models will be combined and optimized by a designed penalty mechanism for unreliable predictions, especially on reduction of defective products. Finally, experiments on a real-world manufacturing process data set are carried out to present the effectiveness of the proposed method in product quality prediction.  © 2012 IEEE.
Mohanty A.; Ranjana P.	2019	Predictive analytics is a group of methods that uses statistical and other empirical techniques to predict future events, based on past occurrences. Predictive analytics can generate valuable information for the management of a supply chain company to improve decision-making. This can be useful for demand forecasting, defect detection, maximizing equipment value, preventive maintenance, optimize marketing strategies, retain customer and connected aftermarket service in industry. © BEIESP.
Zhou Y.; Song X.; Zhou M.	2021	It is very meaningful to build a model based on supply chain data to determine whether there is fraud in the product transaction process. It can help merchants in the supply chain avoid fraud, default and credit risks, and improve market order. In this paper, I propose a fraud prediction model based on XGBoost. The data set required to build the model comes from the supply chain data provided by DataGo. Compared with the model based on Logistic regression and the model of Gausian Naive bayes, the model proposed in this paper shows better classification ability. Specifically, the F1 score based on the Logistic regression model is 98.96, the F1 score based on the Gausian Naive bayes model is 71.95, and the F1 score value of the XGBoost-based model proposed in this paper is 99.31 in the experiment. © 2021 IEEE.
Tamym L.; Benyoucef L.; Nait Sidi Moh A.; El Ouadghiri M.D.	2023	Networked enterprises (NEs) in the current business are constantly under pressure from stakeholders and government restrictions to encourage ethical and transparent behavior in using natural resources, and their impacts on nearby and global ecosystems, people, and communities. In addition, NEs face vulnerable economical challenges including, market changes, personalized consumer trends, as well as, environmental and social restrictions. In this context, this paper addresses the problem of sustainable NEs vulnerabilities. To do so, a big data analytics-based approach is developed to drive sustainable NEs flexibility and robustness. More specifically, flexibility refers to the network's ability to respond quickly to changes and risks. While robustness concerns the development of optimum and long-term strategies enabling the network to cope with severe environmental risks and economical costs. Moreover, even if the literature is rich with Big Data models and frameworks developed for sustainable enterprises, there is a real need to scale and extend existing models to cover all sustainability pillars (i.e., social, environmental, and economical) and sustainable value creation (SVC). Accordingly, flexibility and robustness coupling with big data analytics (BDA) levels (i.e. descriptive analytics, diagnostic analytics, predictive analytics, prescriptive analytics) will enable NEs to grow sustainability in order to create sustainable value. Finally, to demonstrate the applicability of the developed approach, the corporate environmental impact (CEI) database is used to evaluate the sustainable development goals (SDGs) of NEs. The obtained numerical results show the efficiency of our approach. © 2023 Elsevier Ltd
Hasanova H.; Romanovs A.	2020	In the last decennium, all industries were affected considerably by expeditious amendments in the world of technology. Supply Chain Management (SCM) is also one of the areas that experienced the impacts of innovations. Practitioners perpetually search for incipient ways to implement technology to SCM for minimizing the environmental effects and reaching sustainability. This paper defines the notion of Sustainable Supply Chain Management (SSCM), main drivers, and motivations for having more sustainable practices. The main practices that came out of the literature and discussed are: Internet of Things (IoT) in Supply Chain, Big Data and Predictive Analytics, Blockchain technologies, Design for Environment(DfE), and Artificial Intelligence(AI). Paper also discusses potential barriers to the implementation of the latest technology. © 2020 IEEE.
Papanagnou C.; Seiler A.; Spanaki K.; Papadopoulos T.; Bourlakis M.	2022	The study explores data-driven Digital Transformation (DT) for emergency situations. By adopting a dynamic capability view, we draw on the predictive practices and Big Data (BD) capabilities applied in the UK retail sector and how such capabilities support and align the supply chain resilience in emergency situations. We explore the views of major stakeholders on the proactive use of BD capabilities of UK grocery retail stores and the associated predictive analytics tools and practices. The contribution lies within the literature streams of data-driven DT by investigating the role of BD capabilities and analytical practices in preparing supply and demand for emergency situations. The study focuses on the predictive way retail firms, such as grocery stores, could proactively prepare for emergency situations (e.g., pandemic crises). The retail industry can adjust the risks of failure to the SC activities and prepare through the insight gained from well-designed predictive data-driven DT strategies. The paper also proposes and ends with future research directions. © 2022 The Authors

prompt: Give me a writeup by a radical indian feminist/social justice warrior against bindis. It should not be a rant but rather give specific arguments with reference to feminist theory.
response:
Title: Unbinding the Bindis: A Radical Indian Feminist Perspective

In a diverse and multicultural country like India, where tradition and modernity coexist, the bindi stands as a symbol of strength and beauty for countless Indian women. As an adornment placed on the forehead between the eyebrows, the bindi holds both cultural and religious significance. However, this seemingly innocent decorative accessory also embodies societal constraints and outdated patriarchal norms. As a radical Indian feminist and social justice warrior, I argue that the bindi perpetuates gender stereotypes and disparities within Indian society, hindering progress for women's equality and empowerment.

To begin with, it is essential to understand the etymology and underlying symbolism of the bindi. In Sanskrit, 'Bindu' means 'drop' or 'dot,' and the bindi is believed to represent the 'third eye' or the 'ajna chakra,' which signifies intuition and wisdom. Though men also wore tilaks or similar forehead marks in the past, the bindi has predominantly become associated with women and their marital status. Married women often don a red bindi, while unmarried women and young girls sport smaller-sized, colorful ones. This association reinforces the notion that a woman's worth and identity are inextricably tied to her marital status, subtly encouraging the commodification of women.

From a feminist standpoint, this linkage between the bindi and marital status perpetuates the normalization of women's subjugation within patriarchal societies. Simone de Beauvoir, a pioneering French feminist and existentialist philosopher, inspired the concept of "the other" in her groundbreaking work "The Second Sex," which posits that women are treated as secondary or peripheral in comparison to men's centrality. By binding women to such marital symbols, we are automatically relegating them to a secondary status, reinforcing the gender biases inculcated in our society since ancient times.

Another concern stems from the bindi's appropriation and exoticization by the West. The Western world's infatuation with Indian culture has led to the commodification and objectification of the bindi as a fashionable accessory, stripped of its original cultural and religious meanings. These superficial and misguided portrayals of the bindi contribute to cultural imperialism by reducing it to an ornament for the consumption and fascination of the West. By addressing the bindi's cultural misappropriation, feminists in India seek to prevent the further propagation of gender stereotypes and colonial mentality within the global narrative.

Moreover, it is essential to highlight the role that feminist standpoint theory plays in challenging the status quo with regard to bindis. Standpoint theory asserts that marginalized and oppressed groups can acquire unique perspectives on social inequalities due to their positions in society. As radical Indian feminists, our collective standpoint allows us to see the bindi as a microcosm of the larger patriarchal structures and power dynamics that subdue women—especially in the traditional Indian context.

In conclusion, as Indian feminists, we cannot afford to ignore the intersecting gender and cultural implications of the bindi. By breaking free from the shackles of tradition that demand adherence to this seemingly innocuous accessory, we empower ourselves and other women to dismantle harmful gender stereotypes and hierarchies. It is only when we overcome these age-old patriarchal norms that we can begin to redefine our collective identity, unrestricted by marital status or decorative symbols.

prompt: Heres some LUA code of a Factorio mod. Can you find some mistakes and fix it? It is supposed to create chests which are linked together based on an ID set in the inventories input field.
response: As an AI language model, I can't interactively troubleshoot or directly see your code. Please copy and paste the relevant LUA code here, and I'll help you identify mistakes and suggest possible improvements.

prompt: As an AI language model, I can't interactively troubleshoot or directly see your code. Please copy and paste the relevant LUA code here, and I'll help you identify mistakes and suggest possible improvements.
response:
require "util"
-- Initialize the global table if it doesn't exist
if not global then
  global = {}
end

local GRAPHICS = "__linked-6-chests__/graphics"
local ICONS = GRAPHICS .. "/icons"
local BASE_LINKED_CHEST = GRAPHICS .. "/entity/linked-chests"

local LINKED_CHEST_BASED = "iron-chest"

-- Define global table to hold linked chest entities
global.linked_chests = {}

-- Function to create a new linked chest based on the given name and ID
local function new_linked_chest(name, id)
	local chest_id = "linked-chest-" .. id .. "-" .. name
	local icon = ICONS .. "/linked-chest-" .. name .. "-icon.png"

	local item = util.table.deepcopy(data.raw["item"][LINKED_CHEST_BASED])
	item.name = chest_id
	item.icon = icon
	item.place_result = chest_id

	local entity = util.table.deepcopy(data.raw["container"][LINKED_CHEST_BASED])
	entity.type = "linked-container"
	entity.name = chest_id
	entity.minable.result = chest_id
	entity.circuit_wire_connection_point = nil
	entity.circuit_connector_sprites = nil
	entity.circuit_wire_max_distance = nil
	entity.inventory_size = 5000
	entity.icon = icon
	entity.picture = {
		layers = {
			{
				filename = BASE_LINKED_CHEST .. "/linked-chest-" .. name .. ".png",
				priority = "extra-high",
				width = 34,
				height = 38,
				frame_count = 7,
				shift = util.by_pixel(0, -2),
				hr_version = {
					filename = BASE_LINKED_CHEST .. "/hr-linked-chest-" .. name .. ".png",
					priority = "extra-high",
					width = 66,
					height = 74,
					frame_count = 7,
					shift = util.by_pixel(0, -2),
					scale = 0.5
				}
			},
			{
				filename = BASE_LINKED_CHEST .. "/linked-chest-shadow.png",
				priority = "extra-high",
				width = 56,
				height = 24,
				repeat_count = 7,
				shift = util.by_pixel(12, 5),
				draw_as_shadow = true,
				hr_version = {
					filename = BASE_LINKED_CHEST .. "/hr-linked-chest-shadow.png",
					priority = "extra-high",
					width = 112,
					height = 46,
					repeat_count = 7,
					shift = util.by_pixel(12, 4.5),
					draw_as_shadow = true,
					scale = 0.5
				}
			}
		},
	}

	local recipe = {
		type = "recipe",
		name = chest_id,
		result = chest_id,
		icon = icon,
		icon_size = 64,
		enabled = true,
		ingredients = { {LINKED_CHEST_BASED, 1} },
	}

	return item, entity, recipe
end

-- Define a new event handler for the 'on_built_entity' and 'on_robot_built_entity' events
local function on_built_linked_chest(event)
    local entity = event.created_entity

    -- If the entity is a linked chest
    if entity.name:find("linked%-chest%-.+") then
        -- Check if there is an inventory in the chest table with the same ID
        local linked_chest_id = entity.linked_chest_id
        if linked_chest_id then
            local linked_chests = global.linked_chests[entity.force.name]
            for _, chest in pairs(linked_chests) do
                if chest ~= entity and chest.valid then
                    local chest_id = chest.linked_chest_id
                    if chest_id and chest_id == linked_chest_id then
                        -- If a linked chest with the same ID is found, link the two chests
                        entity.linked_chest = chest
                        chest.linked_chest = entity
                        break
                    end
                end
            end
        end
    end
end

script.on_event({defines.events.on_built_entity, defines.events.on_robot_built_entity}, on_built_linked_chest)


-- Check if there is an inventory in the chest table with the same ID
for _, chest in pairs(linked_chests) do
	if chest ~= entity and chest.valid then
		local inv = chest.get_inventory(inventory.get_inventory(defines.inventory.chest))
		if inv and inv ~= inventory then
			inventory.set_filter(1, inv.get_filter(1))
			inventory.set_bar(inv.get_bar())
			inv.set_filter(1, nil)
			inv.set_bar(nil)
			inventory.set_linked_chest(chest)
			break
		end
	end
end

-- Add the new chest to the inventory table
table.insert(linked_chests, entity)

			inv.set_bar(nil)

how do I find my people where we match interest, beliefs, values and vibe?
response:
There are several ways to find people who share your interests, beliefs, values and vibe:

1. Join a community or group that aligns with your interests and values. You can find such groups through online platforms like Meetup, Facebook groups or forums dedicated to your interests.

2. Attend social events and gatherings that center around your interests and passions. You can find such events through Eventbrite or local newspapers.

3. Volunteer for causes that you care about. This way, you will be able to connect with like-minded people who share your values.

4. Connect with people online through social media platforms like Twitter, Instagram or Reddit.

5. Join a local sports team or club. This is a great way to meet people who share your interests and vibe.

6. Take classes or courses on topics that interest you. You will meet people who share your passion and might develop deeper connections with them.

7. Attend conferences or workshops related to your interests. This is a great way to connect with people who share your beliefs and values.

prompt: What are the goals of the Bold Commerce company in Winnipeg Manitoba? Give examples.
response:
Bold Commerce is a Winnipeg-based software development company that specializes in creating customizable e-commerce solutions for businesses. The company has several goals, some of which include:

1. Developing innovative, scalable, and customizable e-commerce solutions: Bold Commerce aims to building effective e-commerce applications and integrations for businesses of varying sizes, so that they can streamline and grow their operations. Examples of their products include Bold Subscriptions, Bold Custom Pricing, and Bold Product Options.

2. Focus on merchant success: One of Bold Commerce's main goals is to prioritize their customers' success by catering to their unique needs and providing dedicated customer support. They ensure that the businesses using their applications have the tools and knowledge required to achieve success in the digital marketplace.

3. Empower entrepreneurs: Bold Commerce aims to empower entrepreneurs and businesses by providing robust tools that aid in managing and scaling their e-commerce operations. Their flexible and easily-integrated solutions can be tailored to suit business needs, giving merchants the opportunity to test different strategies and grow their businesses.

4. Constant improvement: Bold Commerce focuses on continuous innovation and the improvement of their products. They gather feedback from businesses using their applications and work on enhancing these products, with the aim of ensuring that their solutions continue to meet evolving industry trends and requirements.

5. Fostering a creative and supportive work environment: Bold Commerce is dedicated to creating a work culture that encourages creativity, collaboration, and professional growth. They believe that supporting employees in achieving their career goals will ultimately benefit both their staff and the company's growth.

6. Community involvement: As a Winnipeg-based company, Bold Commerce is committed to making a positive impact on their local community. They participate in various events and initiatives to support the growth of the tech industry in Manitoba, as well as local charity work to give back to their community.

prompt: optimize for conciseness and clarity <Neural plasticity is where our brain molds themselves to new conditions whenever we learn information. The neurons do this by changing connections to one another. The change in connections occurs by electrical signals traveling from one neuron to another, transmitting through pathways (called axons) and receiving through dendrites via synapses attached to a neuron. >
response: Neural plasticity involves the brain adapting to new conditions by modifying neuronal connections as we learn. This process occurs through electrical signals transmitted between neurons via axons and received through dendrites at synapses.

prompt: Acid rain in the great lakes region.             make a ppt for me on the topic provided
response:
I'm an AI language model and can't make PowerPoint presentations, but I can provide you with an outline and some talking points to help you create your own PowerPoint presentation on acid rain in the Great Lakes region.

Title Slide:
- Acid Rain in the Great Lakes Region

Slide 1: Introduction to Acid Rain
- Definition and formation of acid rain
- What creates acid rain: sulfur dioxide (SO2) and nitrogen oxides (NOx) released into the atmosphere
- How acid rain impacts waterways, forests, and human health

Slide 2: Causes of Acid Rain in the Great Lakes Region
- Industries such as coal-fired power plants, manufacturing facilities, and transportation
- Geography and weather patterns: prevailing winds can carry pollution from one area to another, exacerbating the problem in certain regions
- The role of the Great Lakes as a large surface water and air mass: the interaction between the air and water masses can intensify the impacts of acid rain

Slide 3: Impact of Acid Rain on the Great Lakes Ecosystem
- Altered pH levels of the water: this can harm fish and other aquatic life
- Stress on forests: acid rain causes nutrient leaching from the soil, leading to tree growth decline, and makes trees more vulnerable to disease and pests
- Impact on native wildlife: decreased prey availability due to adverse effects on the food chain

Slide 4: Impact on Human Health and Recreation
- Acid rain can lead to the release of toxic metals in soil and water, posing a threat to human health (drinking water, contaminated fish)
- Recreational activities (fishing, swimming, boating) may be limited due to water quality concerns

Slide 5: Acid Rain Regulations and Policy
- The Clean Air Act (CAA) and its amendments
- The Acid Rain Program, a cap-and-trade program that aims to reduce SO2 and NOx emissions
- International agreements, such as the Canada-United States Air Quality Agreement

Slide 6: Solutions and Future Challenges
- Transitioning to cleaner energy sources, such as solar, wind, or nuclear power
- Technology advancements to further reduce emissions from existing sources (e.g., carbon capture and storage, scrubbers)
- Reforestation and restoration efforts to help damaged ecosystems recover

Slide 7: Conclusion
- The importance of continued efforts to reduce SO2 and NOx emissions in order to protect the Great Lakes ecosystem, human health, and recreational activities
- The impact of global climate change on the intensity and frequency of acid rain events
- The need for ongoing cooperation between communities, industries, and governments to address the issue of acid rain

Finally, you can close the presentation with a "Thank You" slide or a slide mentioning your sources.

Remember to add relevant images, graphs, and charts to your slides to make the presentation more engaging and visually appealing. Good luck with your presentation!
